text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Armed men who grabbed 80,000 pounds from a teller at a co-operative society in Limassol are still at large.
- A military dialogue aimed at reducing tension between the two sides has started, says a United Nations envoy.
- The government refuses to budge on its decision to contract out postal work to the private sector.
- Daring Limassol robbers get away with 80,000 pounds in broad daylight.
- The government is to extend its diplomatic presence in the European Union.
- Communist Akel expresses its opposition to a bill banning strikes in essential sectors.
- Police inquiries over allegations people were getting kickbacks for government arms purchases stall at practical problems.
- The United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus sets an informal deadline of two weeks for the national guard and Turkish forces to take a position on U.N. proposals to reduce military tension.
- The British and American initiative on the Cyprus problem has an expiry date. Britain wants talks between the two sides concluded by the summer.
